title: Ken Fisher, Joe Biden and the Merciless Young
summary: Sexism is only a pretext that allows one competitor to damage another while playing the hero.. Billionaire money manager Ken Fisher made a crass joke. "Money, sex-those are the two most private things for most people," he told them. The advice he gives his employees is to approach potential investors sensitively. Otherwise, he said, it's like "going up to a woman in a bar and saying, 'Hey, I want to talk about what's in your pants.' "

title: Servicemen's Savings Shouldn't Fund Russia and China
summary: A change in federal pension policy will have perverse consequences.. This tragedy will soon become reality unless a decision by the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board is immediately reversed.

summary: More evidence of the benefit of trials based on genetic variants.. Despite many promising leads, more than 120 drug treatments for Alzheimer's disease have failed. title: Erdogan's Clean Sweep

title: How the Democrats Will Keep Texas Red
summary: Their extreme energy policies ensure they'll stay locked out of the Lone Star State.. summary: Erdogan is no friend to America. He's a dictator with strange ideas, not unlike Nicolás Maduro.. Turkish citizens are wildly optimistic about the invasion of Syria that began Oct. 9. summary: An acquittal should allow a president to run for a third term.. Walter Scheidel is here already.

title: 7 Inside Stories Behind the 'Friends' Set Design
summary: Joey and Chandler's recliners. The Central Perk sofa. That weird gold frame on Monica's door. As the sitcom turns 25, the set designers dish on their décor decisions. AS YOU'VE probably heard, this fall marks 25 years since the premiere of "Friends," NBC's wildly popular sitcom about a sextet of pals set in a carefully rendered New York City. Whether the gang was cracking wise in their improbably spacious Greenwich Village digs or fretting in the Central Perk cafe, their surroundings-a vibrant, layered mix of flea-market finds and sight gags-ushered viewers into a distinct world. Here, "Friends" production designer John Shaffner and set decorator Greg Grande, both of Los Angeles, rewind some of its greatest décor hits.

title: Zuckerberg's Plan for Free Speech on Facebook
summary: Facebook should allow a variety of independent overseers to rate material on its platform, and then let users choose which raters to take seriously and which to ignore.. Mark Zuckerberg is wise to have decided that " Facebook shouldn't be making so many important decisions about speech on its own" ("Facebook Stands for Free Expression," op-ed, Oct. 18). But his plan to establish an "independent Oversight Board" is another variant of such central control, and very off-brand for a social network.

title: Think Again About What Rural Voters Want
summary: Crispin Sartwell's insistence that rural America wants independence and autonomy from the government would be more convincing if farmers didn't recently receive an additional $16 billion in farm subsidies from the Trump administration in July.. Regarding Crispin Sartwell's "Rural Voters' Pride and the Left's Prejudice" (op-ed, Oct. 17): The question, "What's the matter with Kansas?" has a long history. Emporia Gazette editor William Allen White first wrote those words in an 1896 editorial, still taught in quality U.S. history classes. As a small-town conservative, White blamed his fellow Kansans for their economic woes due to their irrational infatuation with the socialist bluster of another man of the prairie, perennial populist presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan.

title: Blackouts Threaten Small Communities in California
summary: As this scenario plays out (it will take 10 years, PG&E tells us), I fear that the cachet of our small towns will degrade as businesses move elsewhere.. Four months ago my husband and I moved from the crowded Bay Area after living there for 40 years to enjoy the peace and tranquility of the Sierras. The power outage was difficult, but we're preparing ourselves for future events. ("PG&E Warns on Blackouts," Business, Oct. 19).

title: I See What Lethal Damage Cigarettes Have Wrought
summary: As a cardiologist, I see patients every day who have had their lives destroyed by tobacco.. Barton Swaim's review of Sarah Milov's "The Cigarette: A Political History" (Bookshelf, Oct. 14) includes the sentence: "The implied suggestion that smoking dwarfs murder as a societal problem is preposterous." This statement displays an unfortunate misunderstanding of the enormity of the suffering created by smoking. Without denying the tragedy of murder, it is very clear that the number of deaths attributed directly to smoking do indeed dwarf murder.

summary: Abnormal weather and wind patterns contribute to 'rare event'. A hole in the ozone layer located near the Earth's South Pole is the smallest it has been since first being discovered in the 1980s, NASA said.

While royal infighting and a muddy battle occupy much of the movie, another war rages in real life: who had the better hair?

summary: Moves are part of an effort to help tame volatility in short-term rate markets. The New York Fed added permanent and temporary liquidity to financial markets Wednesday.

title: For $8 Million, the House Where I.M. Pei Dreamed Up His Designs
summary: The four-story townhouse where the late architect, best known for the Louvre pyramid, lived modestly with his wife of 72 years, is going on the market. For more than 45 years, the architect I.M. Pei and his wife, Eileen Pei, lived in a modest house on New York's Sutton Place, a historic enclave on Manhattan's east side known for its prewar townhomes, tree-lined streets and expansive East River views. While the neighborhood attracted many famous faces over the years-Marilyn Monroe, Arthur Miller and Freddie Mercury all called it home-the Peis lived there discreetly, surrounded by their extensive art collection.

title: 4 Paris Restaurants That Are Secretly Affordable
summary: How to tuck into a divine meal in Paris without forking over a fortune? Stick to lunch. These 4 ambitious neighborhood bistros offer 3-course midday meals for 25 euros or less. EVERY TUESDAY for the past two years, an old man with tortoiseshell glasses has lunched at Les Arlots in Paris's 10th arrondissement. "He sits in the same seat, at the same hour," said chef and owner Thomas Brachet. Down a quiet street over in the 20th arrondissement, the same group of seven architects shows up for lunch at least once a week at La Vierge, where the menu changes everyday, making a repeat visit all the more appealing. The price tag is equally attractive. Both Les Arlots and La Vierge offer two or three courses for under 25 euros. The prix fixe, founded by the godfather of French cuisine Georges-Auguste Escoffier in the early 1900s, is nothing new. But a different kind of formule, as it's commonly called, has emerged of late-specifically between the hours of noon and 2 p.m. on weekdays over in the les quartiers gourmands on the Right Bank. Rather than offering bargain hunters a discount for ordering multiple courses off the standard a la carte menu, these prix fixe meals stand alone. They change weekly-or more-and you're usually spoiled silly.
